transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: From WBEZ Chicago, it's distributed by Public Radio International. I'm Ira Glass, and this is our 500th episode. And what does that feel like? Well, it feels like both a milestone and it feels like nothing. It fills like an odometer clicking over.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: I was talking to the show's senior producer, Julie Snyder, about this. She's been here for 15 of the show's 17 years, since episode number 58.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: Five hun-- what-- I just-- I just come to work. I do my job. I go home.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Play each ballgame the best I can.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: Yeah, exactly.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: [LAUGHTER]

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: No, it really is a blur.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: It is a blur. And over the last few weeks here at the radio show, we talked about what we should do for the 500th episode. And like, first of all, should we mark it at all? You know what I mean? Like 500 shows on the radio actually isn't that big of a deal for most programs. Like Terry Gross, she knocks through 500 shows like every two years. Doesn't even notice. Just spins right by them. Lots of shows are like that.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: But, you know, the kind of show that we do here, it takes three or four months to make each episode. So that is different. And besides that, you know, 500, the number 500-- that is a number you notice. And if we didn't do something today, like that would feel weird, you know?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: So anyway, so as we talked about different things that we could do for this episode, at some point, Julie had the idea that it might be fun to go back to the archives and choose favorite moments from the last 499 episodes. And all this hour, you're going to be hearing the producers of the program, the people who find the stories and who put them together each week, talking about their very favorite moments that we have ever put on the radio.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And the reasons that the producers picked their favorites, I think, are different than the reasons that most listeners would give. Some of them chose stories that had been, I have to say, completely forgotten by the rest of the staff for years. Some chose just, like, one little section of script. Some chose, like, a scene that secretly made them cry and they never told the rest of us. They said things like this.

transcript.speaker: Male Speaker
transcript.text: When I heard that, I was like, wow, that's one articulate bank robber.

transcript.speaker: Female Speaker
transcript.text: And then as it unfolds, you just realize, like, no, no, no, no, no, no, no.

transcript.speaker: Male Speaker
transcript.text: I felt like I'd been hit by a car or something. But in a nice way. [LAUGHS]

transcript.speaker: Female Speaker
transcript.text: It just made me really mad. Do you remember this? (STAMMERING) It's mind-blowing.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And so I am really excited to play you the stuff that we have found. And let's just jump in.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Julie Snyder, our senior producer, is the mastermind behind a lot of our most ambitious shows, like Harper High School episodes, if you've heard those. And she came into the studio with a list of favorite stories from over the years, starting with a shortie.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: It's only like a minute long.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: OK.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: It's really, really lovely writing that I have thought about ever since it aired, I don't know, 12 years ago, 14 years ago.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Wow. What in the world are you talking about?

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: It's from Sarah Vowell's Trail of Tears story. Can you guess it?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Hold on.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: That's a whole show.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Like America is a country that hits you but-- that's not the moment.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: It is.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: It is?

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: It is.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: I can't remember the set-up for it. I just remember the punchline of it.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: Well, the set-up-- OK. Well, so the story, right, is that Sarah is part Cherokee. And she and her twin sister Amy go on this road trip, going from Georgia driving to Oklahoma, following the Trail of Tears. And--

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: That their ancestors had walked before them.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: Exactly. That their ancestors have walked when the Cherokee were expelled from Georgia. And it's super depressing. I mean, what would a trip like that be? It is. It's just depressing. So it's very hard to know what to do with all these feelings. And so that's where her writing picks up. You want to hear it?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: OK. It's "Trail of Tears," starting at 45:14.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: OK, here we go.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: [MUSIC - CHUCK BERRY, "BACK IN THE USA"]

transcript.speaker: Sarah Vowell
transcript.text: The most happiness I find on the trip is when we're in the car and I can blare the Chuck Berry tape I brought. We drive the trail where thousands died, and I listen to music and think, what are we supposed to do with the grizzly past? I feel a righteous anger and bitterness about every historical fact of what the American nation did to the Cherokee. But at the same time, I'm an entirely American creature. I'm in love with this song and the country that gave birth to it.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Vowell
transcript.text: [MUSIC - CHUCK BERRY, "BACK IN THE USA"]

transcript.speaker: Sarah Vowell
transcript.text: Listening to "Back in the USA" while driving the Trail of Tears, I turn it over and over in my head. It's a good country. It's a bad country. Good country. Bad country. And of course, it's both. When I think about my relationship with America, I feel like a battered wife. Yeah, he knocks me around a lot, but boy, he sure can dance.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Vowell
transcript.text: [MUSIC - CHUCK BERRY, "BACK IN THE USA"]

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: Isn't that so nice?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: It's perfect.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: I know. I remember-- I remember when she wrote it. I remember reading it. I remember when it aired. I just thought it was great. I love that writing. And I think about it all the time. I think about it for so many times when trying to put stuff-- like how do you hold two thoughts together?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: You mean about this country?

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: Yes. All right, you want another one?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Mm-hm.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: OK, you want to do "Testosterone"?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: All right. I really do-- so this is another one. I'll just continue to do these through how they personally affected me.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Good.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: So "Testosterone," this is the one where I feel so bad for you guys. I feel really bad for men. This blew my mind, the interview that Alex did with Griffin Hansbury.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Griffin Hansbury.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: Yeah. And so Griffin was talking to Alex about-- Griffin was born a woman and went to Bryn Mawr, and was a feminist, and really-- you know what I mean?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Yeah, lesbian feminist.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: Lesbian feminist. And then so then, Griffin decided to transition, and so he started taking testosterone. And he started taking pretty intense amounts, apparently.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Like way more than a man has.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: Yeah, it's like, I think, twice. And so this part of the interview is when Griffin is telling Alex about the effects of the testosterone.

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: The most overwhelming feeling is the incredible increase in libido and change in the way that I perceived women and the way I thought about sex. Before testosterone, I would be riding the subway, which is the traditional hotbed of lust in the city. And I would see a woman on the subway, and I would think, she's attractive. I'd like to meet her.

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: What's that book she's reading? I could talk to her. This is what I would say. There would be a narrative. There would be this stream of language. It would be very verbal.

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: After testosterone, there was no narrative. There was no language, whatsoever. It was just, I would see a woman who was attractive-- or not attractive. She might have an attractive quality, nice ankles or something, and the rest of her would be fairly unappealing to me. But that was enough to basically just flood my mind with aggressive pornographic images, just one after another.

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: It was like being in a pornographic movie house in my mind. And I couldn't turn it off. I mean, I could not turn it off. Everything I looked at, everything I touched turned to sex.

transcript.speaker: Alex Blumberg
transcript.text: What did you do with that? I mean, what did you think?

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: Well, I felt-- I felt like a monster, a lot of the time. And it made me understand men. It made me understand adolescent boys, a lot. Suddenly, hair sprouting, and I'm turning into this beast. And I would kind of-- I would really kind of berate myself for it.

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: I remember walking up Fifth Avenue, and there was a woman walking in front of me. And she was wearing this little skirt and this little top. And I was looking at her ass. And I kept saying to myself, don't look at it, don't look at it. And I kept looking at it.

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: And I walked past her, and this voice in my head kept saying, turn around to look at her breasts. Turn around, turn around, turn around. And my feminist female background kept saying, don't you dare, you pig. Don't turn around. And you know, I fought myself for a whole block, and then I turned around and checked her out.

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: And before, it was cool. When I would do a poetry reading, I would get up and I would read these poems about, you know, women on the street. And I was a butch dyke, and that was very, very cutting edge, and that was very sexy and raw. And now I'm just a jerk. You know?

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: [BOTH LAUGH]

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: And then Alex's final question, when they talk-- you know, when Alex is, um--

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: I know exactly. I know it so well because it's one of my favorite ever posed on our show.

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: I know.

transcript.speaker: Alex Blumberg
transcript.text: Are there other ways that you feel like testosterone has altered the way you feel or perceive?

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: Something that happened after I started taking testosterone-- I became interested in science. I was never interested in science before.

transcript.speaker: Alex Blumberg
transcript.text: No way. Come on, are you serious? [LAUGHS]

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: I'm serious. I'm serious.

transcript.speaker: Alex Blumberg
transcript.text: You're just setting us back 100 years, sir.

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: I know I am. I know--

transcript.speaker: Griffin Hansbury
transcript.text: [BOTH LAUGH]

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Both Julie and another producer on the radio show, Robyn Semien, surprised me by choosing as one of their favorites this interview that we have never replayed from an episode we have never rerun. This hasn't aired since September 2005. This is the show that we did immediately after Hurricane Katrina hit New Orleans. And what they each wanted to play was the same interview from that show. It was an interview with this woman named Denise Moore.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Denise Moore had stayed behind in New Orleans with her mom, who was a nurse at Memorial Hospital. She was essential personnel, so she had to stay. And her mom asked Denise to stay with her, and also her niece and her niece's two-year-old.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And in this interview, Denise just tells me what happened to them over the course of the first few days after the hurricane. Here's Robyn talking about that interview. She heard this on the radio. She wasn't on staff back then.

transcript.speaker: Robyn Semien
transcript.text: The shock to my system that happened, listening to that, was so severe that it's one of those shows where I remember exactly where I was. And it's everything that you've heard on the news so far up until that point. I mean, this was kind of Katrina, wall-to-wall media coverage about the Superdome and the convention center.

transcript.speaker: Robyn Semien
transcript.text: But just hearing it, I didn't have a way to really let it affect me until I heard one woman's experience, and to let her kind of lay out exactly what was going on. I mean, I don't think I fully realized how desperate I was at the time to have something make sense until I heard this.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: I remember when we put that show together, we all knew that there had already been lots of coverage of Katrina everywhere. And we thought the one thing that we could do was that till then, when you heard from people in New Orleans in the news, it was mostly in tiny little soundbites. And we thought the one contribution we could make was just let people talk longer. You know, it's easier to connect emotionally when you hear more.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And so Denise is one of the interviews where this happens. And what happened to Denise after the flood is the hospital where her mom works at, she stays there for a couple days, then it gets shut down. And then everyone is ordered to move to the convention center, where they're told that there'll be buses to take them to safety out of the city. So they go.

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: And when we arrived, there were people all over the street, under the bridge. And we're like, why are these people on the street? Why aren't they in the convention center? And when we got there, people were saying, you don't want to go in there.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Did you go inside at all?

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: Not until the next day.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: What'd you see?

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: Inside?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: A sewer. A sewer, literally. Stepping in feces, stepping in urine, all over the carpet. And people were sitting close as they could to the doors, but the smell was overwhelming.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: So then what do you do? Like what's the best you can do?

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: I actually stopped eating the minute we got there. I wouldn't eat or drink anything. 'Cause I figured if you don't put nothing in, nothing's coming out. I was in the Army. But even at that, I still had to use the bathroom. It was ridiculous.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And where'd you all sleep?

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: We slept on the sidewalk. And then what my mom wanted me to make sure I tell you, what they kept doing the whole time, was tell us to line up for the buses that never came. It was like they were doing drills every four hours.

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: You all have to line up for the bus. And if you bum-rush the bus, they're just going to take off without you, and nobody's going to get to go anywhere. You have to line up. You have to be in a straight line. We're talking about old people in wheelchairs and women with babies, in lines waiting for buses that you know goddamn well aren't coming. Like they were playing with us.

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: And then the story became, they left us here to die. They're going to kill us.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: You mean that's what people were saying to each other?

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And is that what you believed?

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: I was almost convinced.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: That basically--

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: 'Cause I kept having a vision of them opening that floodgate on us, of my niece and her baby floating away from me, screaming. And I just knew it. And then the next morning, I heard from somebody that they actually were going to open that floodgate. So by the time the rumors started that the National Guard was going to kill us, I almost halfway believed it.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And so people were saying, basically, they just brought us here. They're going to leave us here to die?

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: Yeah. That's what we thought. The police kept passing us by. And the National Guard kept passing us by, with their guns pointed at us.

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: And because they wouldn't-- when you see a truck full of water and people have been crying for water for a day and a night, and the water truck passes you by? Just keeps going? How are we supposed to believe these people were here to help us? It was almost like they were taunting us. And then don't forget, they kept lining us up for buses that never showed up.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: We thought they were playing with us. And that best-case scenario. And the worst-case scenario, they want us to either kill each other or die. [LAUGHS INCREDULOUSLY] Or they were going to kill us.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Why didn't people just walk away? That's what I don't understand. Couldn't you just--

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: We weren't allowed. The police-- people kept trying to go up the bridge so they could go to Algiers, and they'd be turned away. And they'd be sent back down.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And literally, they would just, like, go a couple streets away and somebody would send them back?

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: They'd go up the bridge to go across to the west bank, where it was dry.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Right.

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: And lights were on, you know? And the National Guard was up there with guns. They turned them back with guns. And the governor gave orders to shoot to kill. You couldn't get through them.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: So people in groups would go up the bridge, trying to get across the river. People who had family across the river couldn't get across the river. They were not letting us out of there. They wasn't letting nobody in. So we were trapped. I can't even express it.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Denise Moore
transcript.text: I guess someday it'll calm down, and I'll be able to just cry like a normal person. But I feel like if I started crying now, I'd never stop.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: That was Denise Moore in 2005. The next producer we have is Nancy Updike. Nancy is the only person other than me who's working here now at the show who was actually here at the very beginning of the program. She moved to Chicago, and then a week later, we did our first episode.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And what did you want to hear on today's show?

transcript.speaker: Nancy Snyder
transcript.text: I want to hear John Hodgman's story, from "The Real Story." Do you remember this?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: I think about this story all the time because the beginning of it is so beautiful.

transcript.speaker: Nancy Snyder
transcript.text: It's-- I mean, I think it's one of the best pieces of writing that's ever been on the show. It's so inviting and funny, and it keeps making these turns.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: OK, so looking this up on our website, this is Episode 232, February 2003. Let's hear that.

transcript.speaker: John Hodgman
transcript.text: Here is something I'm not quick to admit, even to close friends-- never mind on the radio. Every day for the past several years, I have been working on a screenplay. This, of course, is shameful on its face, but it gets worse-- believe me.

transcript.speaker: John Hodgman
transcript.text: Working on my screenplay has been very hard, because the story I'm telling is long and complex and important. It's also difficult because I'm not actually writing anything down. Until recently, I would only think about it, night after night, lying in bed, rewriting my screenplay in my head. And as this process tends to make me sleepy, I have actually not gotten very far.

transcript.speaker: John Hodgman
transcript.text: I began my screenplay on May 19, 1999, a date that may resonate with some of you who may already guess at the other main challenge of my project, the one that lends it the extra measure of sad delusion and ultimate futility that accompanies the writing of any screenplay. And that is that my screenplay has already been written by someone else, and it is called , ,

transcript.speaker: John Hodgman
transcript.text: [MUSIC - " THEME"]

transcript.speaker: Nancy Snyder
transcript.text: It's perfect.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: [LAUGHS]

transcript.speaker: Nancy Snyder
transcript.text: It's perfect. And then the whole essay, it makes this incredible turn at the end to his mom dying. And that's why he's been obsessively rewriting in his head, that he's turning away from this terrible thing that's happening.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Nancy Updike, talking about John Hodgman's writing. When I sat down in the studio with Sarah Koenig to talk about her favorite moments to play on the show today, her favorites included some of Nancy's writing. And just to introduce Sarah, she's been here at the show for nearly a decade. She's reported lots of stories.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: She's filled in as host now and then, most recently of the "Coincidences" show. And she brought a whole list of favorites into the studio. And she said some of Nancy's writing has just stayed with her.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Koenig
transcript.text: Do you remember all that nice writing, and I was listening to, "I'm From the Private Sector and I'm Here to Help," when she went to Iraq.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: There's a passage about-- are you going to talk about the passage about that one guy who's leading the--

transcript.speaker: Sarah Koenig
transcript.text: Hank.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Hank. Where she describes Hank.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Koenig
transcript.text: Yeah, that whole opening thing with Hank, she has this light touch, and it's funny. And you immediately feel like, oh, I know who this guy is. So this is show number 266. It's from, I think, 2005. 2004, maybe.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: It's 2004. It's June 2004. And it's pretty early in the coverage of the private contractors in Iraq.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Koenig
transcript.text: Right. And one of the companies she focused on was this security company called Custer Battles. And it turned out that they were kind of in some trouble. And so she just hangs out with Hank for a while.

transcript.speaker: Nancy Updike
transcript.text: Hank is the man who was brought in to clean up Custer Battles' PSD operation. Hank has a vision for the kind of men he wants working for him.

transcript.speaker: Hank
transcript.text: Steely-eyed, flat-bellied professionals.

transcript.speaker: Nancy Updike
transcript.text: It's possible Hank came up with this description by looking in the mirror. He's a 49-year-old man with small blue eyes, a former paratrooper and ranger. The son of a decorated soldier. Married to the daughter of a soldier. Father of two soldiers, one of whom was in Iraq and is now in Afghanistan on a mission he can't talk about.

transcript.speaker: Nancy Updike
transcript.text: Hank is cryptic. He doesn't want me to use his last name. He won't even tell me what rank he achieved. I looked it up later-- lieutenant colonel.

transcript.speaker: Nancy Updike
transcript.text: He's done private security work overseas before. He won't give details, of course. But he will-- and this is the thing about Hank-- he will poke fun at it.

transcript.speaker: Hank
transcript.text: So you gotta get the look, the security guy look. Serious, I'm dead serious about this business. I'm steely-eyed and I'm scanning the horizon constantly. And usually when you go to-- like if I go to Africa or someplace like that, and you're on some kind of security mission, it takes you about two seconds to get off the plane, look around, and say, oh, there's somebody else on a mission.

transcript.speaker: Hank
transcript.text: And you kind of sidle up to them, and you go, SAS? And they nod, and then they go, Rangers? And you go-- you kind of nod. And then finally you ask, who are you working for? Of course, he can't tell. He asks you, and you can't tell.

transcript.speaker: Hank
transcript.text: And then you-- [LAUGHS] And then you wander off, you see? But you had that initial, like dogs sniffing each other, you do. But it's very easy to pick the guys out. They all got the look.

transcript.speaker: Nancy Updike
transcript.text: So he wants his PSD guys to have the look.

transcript.speaker: Hank
transcript.text: Steely-eyed, flat-bellied professionals.

transcript.speaker: Nancy Updike
transcript.text: And he walks around doing that look. But he also knows it's all a bit of a put-on. A man dance, as he calls it. And with tens of thousands of American military and ex-military and private military in Iraq right now, it's very possible that we are standing in the middle of the largest man dance on the planet.

transcript.speaker: Nancy Updike
transcript.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: OK, so what else you got?

transcript.speaker: Sarah Koenig
transcript.text: I have to say, this story, the one I'm going to pick right now, is the one, sort of, if people don't know the show, this is the one where I'm like, just listen to this one. It's from 2007. It's "Duty Calls." It's Josh Bearman's story about his family.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Oh yeah, that's a really beautiful story.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Koenig
transcript.text: And it's so deftly done, in this way where if you really think about what the story's about-- it's like in someone else's hands, it could just be this cliche of like, oh, you know, my mom's an alcoholic and my brother's a screw-up. And all the cliches that could go along with that. And you know who these people are.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Koenig
transcript.text: And then you listen to his and you realize, like, no, you don't know. And it's so compelling. And everyone in it, it turns out to be so likable, you know? You sort of-- and that's, I feel like, in a way, the surprise of the story, which is also super raw in parts.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Which part should we play?

transcript.speaker: Sarah Koenig
transcript.text: I don't know. The scene that really got me is when he talks to his-- it's a conversation between Josh and his mom. And it starts at 19:07. Are you on the thing?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Mm-hm.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Koenig
transcript.text: If you start it at 19:07, where they just have this conversation, and so much is happening in the course of this conversation, where like, he's sort of angry and she gets kind of defensive. And then she sort of says this really honest thing that makes you understand how she's been feeling all this time.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Yeah, OK, so this is episode 334, from June of 2007.

transcript.speaker: John Bearman
transcript.text: Take, for example, the hurricane that hit Florida months before the paramedics came for my mom. As the Category 5 storm was making landfall, David decided to go for a drive. He was pulled over by the cops, which wasn't that surprising since the car had no registration, no insurance, no working taillights, and a cracked windshield. David, who had no license-- and maybe had taken some pills to boot-- had been pulled over twice already for having that car on the road. He was thrown in jail for a week, and my mother was left all alone.

transcript.speaker: Josh's Mother
transcript.text: I mean, I was sitting here in total darkness. I mean, there weren't even any streetlights on. You know, water's falling down. Everything was so chaotic. And then, of course, I started drinking out of control, and that was, you know-- it just started out saying, I just want a little relief from this insanity, and it made me even more insane.

transcript.speaker: John Bearman
transcript.text: How come you didn't call me during that whole period?

transcript.speaker: Josh's Mother
transcript.text: Maybe because I really didn't know what to say, Josh.

transcript.speaker: John Bearman

transcript.text: What can theater possibly do for you in this situation? You know? It seems like such an old-fashioned idea that it can do anything.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: So there's this one scene in the play.

transcript.speaker: Female Speaker
transcript.text: Where'd you get these clothes from?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And it's a story of this girl named Candace. And Candace basically wanted better clothes so the other kids at school wouldn't laugh at her. And she steals some clothes from Nike Town and she gets in trouble. She gets caught.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And then she joins a gang to earn some money and be more popular. Her mom finds some drugs in the house, and a gun, and feels completely betrayed because that was not how she raised her daughter. And one thing leads to another, and Candace gets locked up.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Then the girl narrating the story says, and this is how Candace feels about her mom now. And then all the girls in the play come out on the stage and stand in a line, facing their mothers and grandmothers who are right there in front of them.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

transcript.speaker: Girls
transcript.text: (SINGING) Mama, I'm sorry for what I have done. I was arrested and ended up here in the Audy Home. Oh, I'm sorry for putting you through all of this. I know you are mad about the good times that we miss. I'm ready to come back home. I'm willing to make a change.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: One of the verses goes, Mama, I'm sorry for making you come to court, for almost losing your job to give me moral support. Mama, I'm sorry for putting you through all the stress, for making you worry yourself and depressed. I'm ready to come back home. I'm willing to make a change.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And by this time, the girls are all crying. The parents are all crying. And each girl has a cut-out-- you know, like a little heart, like on Valentine's Day? Like that, made from red construction paper. Like the size of your palm. And written on each one is the words "I'm sorry."

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: And each girl goes out to the audience, to where her mom is sitting or her grandma is sitting and hands her the heart. And the parents are crying, and the kids are crying, and everybody is hugging. It was really something.

transcript.speaker: Girls
transcript.text: (SINGING) I'll do anything for you, Mama. Please forget about yesterday. Mama, I'm sorry.

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: Here they were, not just saying this to their mothers, but saying it publicly, in front of the world, in front of their friends. Saying this thing that could be so hard to say in any case, you know? Singing it out, and hoping it can heal something that is going to be hard to heal, no matter what you do.

transcript.speaker: Girls
transcript.text: (SINGING) Mama, I'm sorry. I'm sorry. I'm sorry.

transcript.text: (TEARFULLY BUT LAUGHING) Isn't it the worst?

transcript.speaker: Ira Glass
transcript.text: You're crying?

transcript.speaker: Julie Snyder
transcript.text: I find it so sad.
